item.text: Lesson 75
look like
What famous person would you most like to look like?
I'd most like to look like Robert de Niro.
What does he look like?
He's quite good looking. He has dark hair and dark eyes.
Do you look more like your mother or your father?
I look more like my mother.
Do you think it looks like rain or looks as if it is going to rain?
No, I don't think it looks like rain.
Do you think you look like succeeding or look as if you will succeed in learning English quite well?
Yes, I think I look like succeeding in learning English quite well.
travel
journey
just

Explanation.text: The difference between “travel“ and “journey“ is that we generally use “travel“ as a verb and “journey“ as a noun. For example, “I travelled a long way“ or “The journey was long“.

item.text: What's the difference between travel and journey?
The difference between travel and journey is that we generally use travel as a verb and journey as a noun.
Why is it now easier for people to travel to other countries just for the weekend?
It's now easier for people to travel to other countries just for the weekend because traveling is cheaper and faster these days.
What's the longest journey you've ever made?
The longest journey I've ever made is from England to Australia.
of course
Give me a sentence with the words "of course" in it, please.
Could I borrow your pen for a second? Of course you can. He's American. And so, of course, he speaks English.
nowadays
Do you think people are happier nowadays than they were in the past?
Yes, I think people are happier nowadays than they were in the past.
Why?
Because people are healthier and live longer nowadays.
suffer
Have you suffered from any illnesses in the last two years?
No, I haven't suffered from any illnesses in the last two years.
wish
What's your greatest wish in life?
My greatest wish in life is to be happy.
exist
About how long has this building existed for?
This building has existed for more than a hundred years.
remind
in other words
member

Explanation.text: The difference between the words “remember“ and “remind“ is that we remember something ourselves, without help, whereas, if we forget something, somebody reminds us. In other words, they remember for us.

item.text: What's the difference between the words "remember" and "remind"?

The difference between the words "remember" and "remind" is that we remember something ourselves without help, whereas if we forget something, somebody reminds us. In other words, they remember for us.
If you forget the meaning of a word during the lesson, who reminds you of it?
If I forget the meaning of a word during the lesson, the teacher reminds me of it.
If you have an important appointment to keep, which member of your family reminds you to keep it?
If I have an important appointment to keep, my mother reminds me to keep it.
Do I remind you of any member of your family?
No, you don't remind me of any member of my family.
library
What's the difference between a bookshop and a library?
The difference between a bookshop and a library is that a bookshop is a place where we can buy books, whereas a library is a place where we can go to read books and borrow them.
even though
even
not even
When you were a child, did you sometimes have to go to school even though you didn't want to?
Yes, when I was a child, I sometimes had to go to school even though I didn't want to.
Are there some areas of the world where it never gets warm, even in the middle of summer?
Yes, there are some areas of the world where it never gets warm, even in the middle of summer.
Will there be even more people and more cars in the world in a few years time?
Yes, there'll be even more people and more cars in the world in a few years time.
Do you know of a village in this country where they haven't even got water or electricity?
No, I don't know of a village in this country where they haven't even got water or electricity.
to
at
direction

Explanation.text: The difference between the words “to“ and “at“ is that we generally use “to“ when we are moving in the direction of a place, and “at“ when we are there. For example, “I’m going to the table. Now, I’m (standing) at the table“.

item.text: What's the difference between the words "to" and "at"?
The difference between the words "to" and "at" is that we generally use "to" when we are moving in the direction of a place and "at" when we are there.
Give me an example, please.
I'm going to the table, and now I'm at the table.
Are you coming to the school?
No, I'm not coming to the school; I'm at the school.
Am I going to the table?
No, you aren't going to the table; you're standing at the table.
soon
at once
If I go out of the room and say "I'll be back soon", how long will I be?
If you go out of the room and say "I'll be back soon", you'll be maybe 5 or 10 minutes.
If I go out of the room and say "I'll be back at once", how long will I be?
If you go out of the room and say "I'll be back at once", you'll be about one minute or you'll be back almost immediately.
Will it soon be spring?
Yes, it'll soon be spring.
Is the lesson going to finish soon?
Yes, the lesson is going to finish soon.
How soon do you think it will be before everybody in the world has enough money in order to live a comfortable life?
I think it'll be a long time before everybody in the world has enough money in order to live a comfortable life.
Which would get you home sooner: a bus or a car?
I think maybe a car would get me home sooner than a bus.
